title: Create the Gapminder dataset
text:
# Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd
from gapminder import gapminder

# Rename 'lifeExp' to 'life_expectancy' and 'gdpPercap' to 'gdp_per_capita'
gapminder = gapminder.rename(columns={'lifeExp': 'life_expectancy',
                                      'pop': 'population_millions', 
                                      'gdpPercap': 'gdp_per_capita'})

# Convert population to millions
gapminder['population_millions'] = gapminder['population_millions'] / 1_000_000

# Create a new pandas DataFrame from the modified gapminder data
gapminder_df = pd.DataFrame(gapminder)

# Save the DataFrame as a CSV file
gapminder_df.to_csv('gapminder.csv', index=False)

# Print the first 3 rows of the DataFrame
print(gapminder_df.head(3))

       country continent  year  life_expectancy  population_millions  \
0  Afghanistan      Asia  1952           28.801             8.425333   
1  Afghanistan      Asia  1957           30.332             9.240934   
2  Afghanistan      Asia  1962           31.997            10.267083   

   gdp_per_capita  
0      779.445314  
1      820.853030  
2      853.100710

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text: This page examines the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita using the Gapminder dataset. We explore how economic development is associated with improvements in life expectancy over time.

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text: This page examines the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita using the Gapminder dataset. We explore how economic development is associated with improvements in life expectancy over time.

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text:
Data and Visualization

library(ggplot2)


gapminder <- read.csv("gapminder.csv")


ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdp_per_capita, 
                      y = life_expectancy,
                      color = continent)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_x_log10() +
  labs(
    title = "Life Expectancy vs GDP per Capita",
    x = "GDP per Capita (log scale)",
    y = "Life Expectancy",
    color = "Continent"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Country Analysis
text: This page analyzes changes in life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population over time for a specific country using the Gapminder dataset. Here, we focus on the United States to examine long-term development trends from 1952 to 2007.

title: Country Analysis
text: This page analyzes changes in life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population over time for a specific country using the Gapminder dataset. Here, we focus on the United States to examine long-term development trends from 1952 to 2007.

title: Country Analysis
text:
Data and Visualization

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union



gapminder <- read.csv("gapminder.csv")


country_data <- gapminder %>%
  filter(country == "China")

ggplot(country_data, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = life_expectancy, color = "Life Expectancy"), linewidth = 1) +
  geom_line(aes(y = gdp_per_capita / 1000, color = "GDP per Capita (÷1000)"), linewidth = 1) +
  geom_line(aes(y = population_millions / 10, color = "Population (÷10)"), linewidth = 1) +
  labs(
    title = "Trends in China (1952–2007)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Scaled Values",
    color = "Variable"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

title: An Analysis of the Gapminder Dataset
text:
This is my Quarto website for gapminder.
The dataset contains information about these variables in 142 countries over the years 1952 to 2007, with a 5-year interval.

title: Life Expectancy and Population
text: This page examines the relationship between life expectancy and population using the Gapminder dataset. We explore how population size is associated with life expectancy across countries over time.

title: Life Expectancy and Population
text: This page examines the relationship between life expectancy and population using the Gapminder dataset. We explore how population size is associated with life expectancy across countries over time.

title: Life Expectancy and Population
text:
Data and Visualization

library(ggplot2)


gapminder <- read.csv("gapminder.csv")


ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = population_millions, y = life_expectancy)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_x_log10() +
  labs(
    title = "Life Expectancy vs Population",
    x = "Population (millions, log scale)",
    y = "Life Expectancy"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
